items.content_html:
Value Prop

You can now use the Organization Roles system to assign the App Manager role to users and teams in your organization, allowing them to manage all GitHub Apps in your organization. Previously this was a bespoke system specific to Apps, and was not integrated into the roles platform. This means you can now use the Organization Role APIs to assign the App Manager role to users and teams as well.

In addition, you can now assign teams to specific GitHub Apps, instead of just assigning users. While this cannot be done programmatically, you will be able to programmatically (or via SCIM or team sync) manage the members of the team, who are now allowed to manage the GitHub App.

Expected Outcome

More resilient app management patterns, with greater flexibility and scalability for the assignment of the app manager role. This also sets the foundation for the future, where you'll be able to create custom roles such as "View all apps" or "Can create apps" using the new app management permissions, letting your organization members get more access to apps in a safe manner.
items.title: Org-owned Apps can be managed using Teams and the org roles system [Preview]

items.content_html:
Value Prop

You can now add enterprise members as managers of a GitHub App owned by your enterprise.

App managers have full privileges over the application, with one exception: if they modify application permissions, those changes are not automatically accepted by organizations where the app is installed. App managers do not have sufficient privileges to force permission updates onto organizations. Only enterprise admins can update application permissions without requiring approval from each organization.

Expected Outcome

This lets the Enterprise Admin focus their time on managing the enterprise and less time updating applications for their members. In the future, we'll also have enterprise-wide roles for app management, as well as support for enterprise teams.
items.title: Enterprise-owned Apps can be managed individually by users [Preview]

items.content_html:
Value Prop

Introducing metered GitHub Enterprise billing for Visual Studio subscriptions with GitHub Enterprise.

Scaling your GitHub usage is even easier. GitHub is expanding our pay-as-you-go usage-based billing and licensing reporting interface to include GitHub Enterprise (GHE) for Visual Studio subscriptions with GitHub Enterprise usage.

Expected Outcome

We announced pay-as-you-go billing for GHE and GHAS back in August 1, 2024 to give customers flexible self-provisioning and pricing. Since then, we've heard increasing demand to also have the same billing mechanism for accounts using Visual Studio subscriptions with GitHub Enterprise. Now, you not only have greater flexibility with pay-as-you-go billing, but administrators will also have greater control in mapping which users should consume a Visual Studio license versus a GitHub Enterprise metered license.
items.title: Support VSS bundles for metered GHE

items.content_html:
Value Prop

The new repository creation form is a streamlined, custom properties-forward experience that enables organizations to create compliant repositories by default. It allows administrators to link custom properties and policies at the point of creation while providing developers with a more intuitive, modern interface that surfaces relevant options.

Repository creation with required properties

Repository creation without required properties

Expected Outcome

With the new repository creation form you will experience a streamlined, intuitive creation flow that reduces friction while surfacing the right options. Administrators can have confidence that all new repositories meet organizational standards without manual oversight, eliminating the need for approval processes and enabling "secure by default" repository creation at scale.
items.title: Enhanced Repository Creation [Preview]

items.content_html:
Value Prop

Immutable Releases introduces enhanced integrity and security for software distributed via GitHub Releases. With this feature, repository maintainers can publish releases and associated assets as immutable, ensuring that once a release is published, its assets and associated Git tag cannot be altered or deleted. This prevents supply chain attacks that rely on asset modification or tag movement after publication, and provides users with stronger guarantees that the artifacts they consume are exactly as originally published. Immutable Releases also introduces release attestations, allowing consumers to verify the origin and integrity of artifacts—even outside of GitHub.

Expected Outcome

  • Organizations and open-source projects can confidently distribute software through GitHub Releases, knowing assets and tags cannot be tampered with after publication.
  • Consumers and downstream automation will be able to reliably verify that downloaded artifacts are authentic and unmodified, reducing risk in the software supply chain.
  • The introduction of release attestations provides verifiable proof of artifact origin and content, supporting secure end-to-end software delivery.
  • Immutable Releases aligns GitHub Releases with best practices for provenance and immutability, supporting compliance, security, and trust for all users.
items.title: Immutable Releases [GA]

items.content_html:
Value Prop

GitHub will now automatically compute and display checksums (SHA256 digests) for all uploaded release assets, making these digests available both in the UI and via the API. The checksums are generated at the time of asset upload and are immutable, providing a consistent and standardized way for all projects on GitHub to offer checksum data for their releases.

Expected Outcome

Users and automation tools can easily verify that the asset they downloaded hasn't been tampered with after publishing.
items.title: Expose Release Asset Digests [GA]

items.content_html:
Value Prop

Customers depend on the billing usage report to analyze their usage-based charges and build confidence in GitHub’s billing platform. We frequently hear from our customers that the current report is too dense, resulting in files that are too large to work with effectively. By introducing a summarized usage report, we aim to cover the majority of customer use cases in a more accessible format. For those who need full detail, the detailed report will remain available and its underlying query will also be optimized as part of this release.

Expected Outcome

With summarized billing usage reports, customers will be able to self-serve and better understand their GitHub usage. Customers who previously encountered issues—such as reports not generating or being too large to analyze—will now be able to access the insights they expect when requesting billing data.
items.title: Make billing usage reports more useful by providing a summarized report option

items.content_html:
Value Prop

This feature allows users to transform mermaid diagrams and process images on the go with Copilot Vision, leveraging mobile-native capabilities for enhanced productivity.

Expected Outcome

Users can improve their workflows by seamlessly generating and interacting with visual content directly from their mobile devices, reducing reliance on desktop tools.
items.title: Copilot Vision integration in Copilot Chat on GitHub Mobile

items.content_html:
Value Prop

This release introduces a plugin for OPA Gatekeeper, enabling the verification of Artifact Attestations. Integrated with major cloud providers, Gatekeeper acts as a Kubernetes admission controller, allowing enforcement of attestation verification to gate deployments. This ensures that only trusted and verified artifacts are deployed, enhancing end-to-end SDLC security.

Expected Outcome

Organizations using OPA Gatekeeper as their Kubernetes admission controller will be able to enforce attestation verification, enhancing end-to-end build security.
items.title: OPA Gatekeeper support for Artifact Attestations

items.content_html:
Value Prop

Our dashboards for Copilot engagement and impact will provide organizations with insights at the organizational level to maximize the value of Copilot. These dashboards offer data related to onboarding Copilot users, understanding engagement with specific Copilot features, and assessing early indicators of Copilot's impact on the engineering system. By delivering actionable metrics, these dashboards enable organizations to optimize their use of Copilot, enhance productivity, and drive AI-driven innovation.

Expected Outcome

Organizations can expect improved visibility into the adoption and engagement of Copilot, and actionable insights to refine deployment and maximize Copilot's value. Bring a data-driven approach to your deployment and optimization of Copilot. The images below are subject to change.
items.title: Insights for Copilot adoption, engagement and impact [Preview]

items.content_html:
Value Prop

Our new "Default or Advanced" option gives security managers the freedom to choose the setup that best fits their organization, while ensuring security requirements are consistently met across their repositories. This will allow enforcement of security configurations to hold even when some repositories need to use Advanced Setup for code scanning, solving a common customer pain point with security configurations and code scanning.

Expected Outcome

This will result in more repositories with code scanning running properly and fewer repositories that need bespoke security configurations.
items.title: Security Configurations include "Default or Advanced Setup" option for Code Scanning [GA]

items.content_html:
Value Prop

Today, organization administrator is a special "membership type", that isn't assignable using the standard roles and permissions system. The biggest implication of this is that teams cannot be assigned the "organization administrator" role, and requires users to manually be given the role.

When the organization administrator role is supported, administrators will be able to:

  1. Assign the role to a team, which has the side effect of making it possible to @mention all the admins (if you like).
  2. Link that team to an IDP group
  3. Use your IDP to then manage who an administrator of that organization is.

JIT permission management systems, such as PIM, can also use this to elevate users to the "admin group" on demand, to let them take actions that aren't supported by the custom role platform yet, and then automatically drop back to standard permissions.

Expected Outcome

Organization administrator will be a role that can be assigned to a team, like any other role at the organization level. Users in that team (or a child team) will be full administrators of the organization it's assigned in.

In the future, organization administrator will also be available from the enterprise level, so that users and enterprise teams can be assigned that role against multiple organizations at once.
items.title: Organization Administrator as an assignable role [Preview]

items.content_html:
Value Prop

We are adding new capabilities to manage artifact attestations more effectively:

  • Delete attestations: Easily delete artifact attestations through the UI or API to remove unwanted attestations, such as those linked to malicious or vulnerable artifacts.
  • Bulk operations: Use API endpoints to perform bulk actions on attestations, saving time when managing multiple attestations.
  • Advanced filtering: Quickly locate the attestations you need by filtering by predicate type, subject name or creation date.
  • Interactive list view: The attestations list view (<repository>/attestations) will become more interactive. You will be able to select one or multiple attestations to perform bulk actions, such as downloading or deleting. Additionally, you will be able to sort attestations by oldest or newest creation date.

Expected Outcome

Today, users can publish attestations, but once they're published, they have limited controls over them. They cannot delete existing attestations, even if they were created by accident. There is no built-in mechanism to expire attestations, which means they remain active indefinitely. To address this, we want to introduce lifecycle management capabilities that enable users to control the status and EOL of their attestations, including the ability to manage them in bulk.
items.title: Deletion, filtering, and bulk actions for managing artifact attestations [GA]

items.content_html:
Value Prop

Customers will be able to select which secret scanning patterns are included or excluded from push protection.

Expected Outcome

Giving enterprises greater control over which secret patterns are push protected enables them to align product behaviour with their internal policies, ensuring developers are not accidentally pushing secrets to repositories.
items.title: Configuration for push protected patterns in secret scanning [Preview]

items.content_html:
Value Prop

Rust is becoming a more popular languages and more enterprises are adopting it as an alternative to C/C++. Rust support for CodeQL allows organizations to analyse their proprietary Rust codebases for potential security vulnerabilities.

Expected Outcome

Users using Rust to build their applications will start seeing files written in Rust included in the list of files scanned by CodeQL. This means that they will potentially see new CodeQL relevant to Rust. This will help find and fix issues from additional code bases and improve the overall security posture of the applications scanned with CodeQL.
items.title: CodeQL supports Rust [Preview]

items.content_html:
Value Prop

Helm is a package manager for Kubernetes that simplifies the deployment and management of applications on Kubernetes clusters. It's one of the most upvoted customer requests in our open source repository, dependabot-core. This issue adds Dependabot support for Helm dependencies.

Expected Outcome

This enables customers who use Helm to get version updates from Dependabot.
items.title: Dependabot version updates support Helm package manager [GA]

items.content_html:
Value Prop

To enable Dependabot to use packages in private registries, GitHub Advanced Security users have to set up credentials in a dependabot.yml for every repository, which takes a long time for lots of repositories.

Expected Outcome

This feature allows GitHub Advanced Security users to configure Dependabot to access their private registries from the org level.
items.title: Org-level centralized private registry configuration for Dependabot [GA]

items.content_html:
Value Prop

Today, to enable Dependabot at scale for internal repositories in an org, customers must type each repo by hand. Granting access to internal repositories in bulk, without having to type each repository name individually, is a highly requested feature by GitHub Advanced Security customers.

Expected Outcome

GitHub Advanced Security customers can grant Dependabot access to internal repositories in bulk via the Organization Code Security settings page.
items.title: Dependabot can mass-enable access for internal repos from the Organization settings page [GA]

items.content_html:
Value Prop

We aim to improve the visibility and impact of Dependabot by helping GitHub Advanced Security customers prioritize which Dependabot alerts to address first. To achieve this, we will introduce a dedicated Dependabot metrics section in the Security tab at the Organization level. Our first tile in this page will be a vulnerability prioritization funnel.

Expected Outcome

AppSec managers using GitHub Advanced Security can prioritize Dependabot alerts for the repos in their org(s).
items.title: Org-level Dependabot metrics security page [GA]
